node.postTitle: Working Dog Breeds And What They Do

postDescription.postDescription: What are working dog breeds and what do they do? Working dogs are trained to help others and they love the work, because it is still in their DNA.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about dog breeds from their personality and temperament to a little bit of history, health, and care.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
While those breeds did traditionally work (e.g. guarding), today those specific dogs from he Working Dog Group may or may not perform those jobs they were meant for years back.

Today most of the western people take a dog solely to be a pet, ignoring the genetics of the breed.

Fortunately today we do have institutions (police, military, order police, etc) and civilian people that need a dog to do one or more jobs.

These dogs have natural talents that are carefully honed with intensive training. Working dogs are trained to help others and they love the work, because it is still in their DNA.

Working Dog Breeds - Service Dogs

These are special trained dogs that will assist people with all kinds of disabilities, providing vital and often lifesaving support to those who need it most.

Types of Service Dogs

  • Guide Dogs
  • Mobility Assistance Dogs
  • Seizure Alert and Response Dogs
  • Hearing Dogs
  • Diabetic Alert Dogs
  • Allergy Detection Dogs
  • Autism Support Dogs
  • Psychiatric Service Dogs

Check out my blog “8 Types of Service Dogs And What There Jobs Are” for detailed information about service dogs.

Working Dog Breeds - Therapy Dogs

Unfortunately these dogs are not recognized as service dogs, and they do not enjoy the same rights as a service dogs has.

Nonetheless, these dogs perform an important job as well: provide affection, comfort and love to people.

These people can be the handler itself or children, or elderly.

There have been numerous reports that these dogs help many psychological health issues such as anxiety, depression, social skills, and simply improving the moods of the patient.

Dogs of any breed, size, or age can become therapy dogs but they need very good socialization, and training.

Working Dog Breeds - Search and Rescue Dogs

These dogs have an exceptional senses of smell and hearing. The SAR Dogs serve in many different fields: wilderness tracking, natural disaster search, mass casualty events, avalanche rescue, missing persons and cadaver location.

Working Dog Breeds - Types of Search and Rescue Dogs

  • Air-scenting Dogs
  • Trailing Dogs
  • Detection Dogs

Detection dogs have exceptional sense of smell. A detection dog is trained to sniff out a particular substance or a group of substances, his training motivation being positive reinforcement.

Detection dogs are used in law enforcement, wildlife biology, and health care.

The Detection Dog is trained to use its senses to detect substances such as explosives, illegal drugs, wildlife scat, currency, blood, human remains, contraband, cancer, abnormal blood sugar levels, certain types of insects (e.g. bed bugs), mold, termites, truffles, and so much more.

Working Dog Breeds - Police Dogs or The K-9 Unit

The K-9 unit is trained to assist law enforcement in the line of duty. These dogs are used for chasing and apprehending criminal suspects.

In many cases a Police Dog is assigned to one handler for many years or even until retirement and after that most of the times the police officers adopts the retired dog.

In many countries, the intentional injuring or killing of a police dog is a criminal offence.

The most commonly used breeds are the German Shepherd, Belgian Malinois, Dutch Shepherd.

Working Dog Breeds - Military Working Dogs or The K-9 Unit

Military Dogs are trained to assist soldiers in the line of duty. These dogs are used for intimidation, guarding, sentries, scouts, apprehending suspects, attack if the handler gives the command or if the handler himself is injured.

All MWDs in use today are paired with a single individual after their training.

This person is called a handler.

While a handler usually won’t stay with one dog for the length of either’s career, usually a handler will stay partnered with a dog for at least a year, and sometimes much longer.

The latest canine tactical vests are outfitted with cameras and durable microphones that allow dogs to relay audio and visual information to their handlers.

The most commonly used breeds are the German Shepherd, Belgian Malinois, Dutch Shepherd.

Working Dog Breeds - Herding Dogs

Herding Dogs were bred to help ranchers move their livestock.

In addition to herding, a lot of these breeds are naturally good protectors as well, making them good guard dogs and oftentimes reserved around strangers.

Who doesn’t know Lassie the movie star Collie?

Working Dog Breeds - Bird Dogs

Comprised of several types of dogs — pointers (German shorthair), retrievers (Golden or Labrador), setters (English, Irish), flushers (Cocker Spaniel, Springer Spaniel), and water dogs (Poodle, Portuguese Water Dog).

These breeds were developed to help bird hunters find, flush out and retrieve their game.

Working Dog Breeds - Guard Dogs

Guardian breeds, like Giant Schnauzers, Tibetan Mastiffs, Doberman Pinschers, Cane Corso, are oftentimes seen as aggressive and untrustworthy because they take their home guarding role very serious.

Working Dog Breeds - Sight Dogs

Bred for helping hunters track prey by sight, breeds like the Greyhound, Saluki, and the Irish Wolfhound, have an awesome sight and extremely fast.

Working Dog Breeds - Terriers

Often referred to as “terror terriers”, is one of the most notorious dog group.

They were bred to be ostentatious hunters of game.

Most known are the American Staffordshire Terrier, the infamous Jack Russell and the perky West Highland Terrier.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team

authorBio.authorBio:
🍂Hiker Girl 
🐶Thor, the GSD and Belgian Malinois mix, is my soul dog
📷Humble Photographer
🤸‍♀️ Yogi
🌠Stardust
☕ 🍫🥑Lover

postDescription.postDescription: There are 8 Types of Service Dogs. Service Dogs are specially trained to assist people with all kinds of disabilities, providing vital and often lifesaving support to those who need it most.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about dog breeds from their personality and temperament to a little bit of history, health, and care.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
They’re specially trained to assist people with all kinds of disabilities, providing vital and often lifesaving support to those who need it most.

Different Types of Service Dogs

  • Guide Dogs
  • Mobility Assistance Dogs
  • Seizure Response Dogs
  • Hearing Dogs
  • Diabetic Alert Dogs
  • Allergy Detection Dogs
  • Autism Support Dogs
  • Psychiatric Service Dogs

These dogs often also wear vests that say “Do not pet me” or “Guide Dog” or a similar messages that indicates their job.

It is very important to not distract dogs while on the job in order to prevent any accidents to the handler and / or to the dog.

Keep in mind that not all disabilities are obvious. Someone with a service dog may seem perfectly capable, but their dog is necessary for helping them avoid certain allergens or to alert them of oncoming seizures.

Let’s take a look at these amazing dogs and their important jobs in more detail.

Types of Service Dogs - Guide Dogs

Guide dogs are perhaps the best known of all types of service dogs.

They are specially trained to help blind and visually impaired people navigate obstacles and get from one place to another.

One of the most unique traits of guide dogs is the so-called “selective disobedience”.

This allows the dog to obey commands but also to make choices based on their own assessment of a situation.

You’ll usually see guide dogs in a special harness that has a bar for their humans to hold on to for support.

Breeds such as Golden Retrievers, Labradors, and German Shepherds are often selected as guide dogs because of their calm temperaments and very good trainability.

Types of Service Dogs - Mobility Assistance Dogs

Mobility assistance dogs are trained to assist people with mobility issues such as those who are wheelchair-dependent.

They can perform a wide variety of tasks including pulling wheelchairs, opening and closing doors, bringing objects to people, and operating light switches.

In addition these dogs can also assist humans with arthritis, cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, and spinal cord injuries, among others.

Different breeds are selected depending on the handler’s size, but the dogs must be large enough to support their human partner.

Most suitable are Labradors and German Shepherds.

Types of Service Dogs - Seizure Alert and Response Dogs

These type of service dogs has only been active for about 10 years or so, but have made quite an impact on those suffering from certain seizure disorders.

Seizure Response Dogs are trained to assist their handler during and immediately after they have had a certain seizure.

Their tasks can range from finding someone to help their owner, stimulating their owner to help them “wake up” from a seizure, even physically moving their owner if they have a seizure in an unsafe place, bring medicine or a phone to their owner coming out of the seizure.

There is still no scientific understanding of how seizure alert dogs recognize that a seizure is upcoming.

There is also a big controversy about even about the fact if dogs can be specifically trained to alert seizures.

Research does show, however, that some dogs seem to have born seizure detection abilities, and there is plenty of “proof” that seizure alert dogs do their jobs quite well.

Types of Service Dogs - Hearing Dogs

For people with hearing impairments, these types of service dogs assist by alerting them when noises such as alarms, doorbells, timers or crying babies occur.

When the dog hears the sound, they will touch their human and lead toward the noise.

Hearing dogs increase awareness and independence for their owners.

Breeds like golden retrievers, poodles, and cocker spaniels are often chosen for the role of hearing dogs because of their reliability and responsiveness to obedience training.

Types of Service Dogs - Diabetic Alert Dogs

Dogs are trained to sniff the air to detect the blood sugar levels on someone’s breath.

The scent changes associated with either too low to too high blood sugar.

This scent is imperceptible to humans, but dogs can pick up on them and alert their people to blood sugar highs and lows before the levels become dangerous.

Many of these dogs are also trained to go alert others in the household or set off an alarm system if their human needs medical help.

This provides diabetic people with a sense of security they may not have experienced before having a service dog.

Types of Service Dogs - Allergy Detection Dogs

The allergy detection dogs use their unmatchable sense of smell to detect traces of specific substances in the air and foods and are trained to alert their humans of the danger.

This can make a life and death difference for adults as well as for children.

Often, allergy detection dogs work with children, accompanying them to school and activities so that they have more freedom to move around without their parents.

Types of Service Dogs - Autism Support Dogs

Autism Support Dogs provide assistance and emotional support to people with autism.

These dogs can be a big boost in confidence for children and help them connect with other children by acting as an icebreaker.

An Autism Support Dog can also keep the person with autism from running away, they can often track them if they do run off, alert the autistic person of a dangerous situation, and interrupting harmful behavior.

Types of Service Dogs - Psychiatric Service Dogs

A specially trained Psychiatric Service Dogs dog can help its handler remain calm and deal with difficult emotional states.

These dogs can also interrupt destructive behavior, self harming behavior, and even remind their handlers to take medication.

Psychiatric service dogs help provide a comforting barrier in times of distress, and can perform a range of tasks that include protecting their handler’s personal space and turning on lights before their handler enters a room so that they feel safer.

As humans learn to better understand dogs and their awesomely inspiring capabilities, the households with dogs are increasing as well as the list of service for working dogs.

And whether a dog is a trained service or working dog or just a pet, we can all agree: they’re pretty freakin’ amazing at what they do.

Even a pet that has no service or working dog training can provide emotional support or even tasks like picking up objects and so on if their human teaches them.

Knowledge Makes You and Your Dog Happy! Furry Canine Team

node.postTitle: The Complete Guide On Buying A Dog

postDescription.postDescription: Dogs have been bred for all kinds of different tasks. Some dogs were bred for hunting while others have been bred for herding. But what dog breed is the right one for you?

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about dog breeds from their personality and temperament to a little bit of history, health, and care.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Searching for the perfect dog? But you only can find those dog selector quizzes?

Rest assured this is not gonna be a quiz for choosing the best dog. I’m going to explain the basics you need to understand in order to find the perfect match.

In order to know what dog breed is right for you, you have to start by knowing yourself, asses your financials, living and lifestyle situation, and what are the disadvantages of owning a dog.

These are just some questions to ask yourself in order to understand your personal situation. Knowing this is a great start but knowing the general differences in dogs is even better.

Dogs have been bred for all kinds of different tasks. Some dogs were bred for hunting while others have been bred for herding. They also have different levels of intelligence which can make it hard for you as a potential owner to control the dog.

ARE YOU READY TO BE RESPONSIBLE?

Of course, sweet puppy faces, and fluffy fur, and puppy breath are so darn cute no matter what breed you look at. But dogs are puppies for only a short period o time.

Will you still love and care for the dog as a teenager, adult, and senior?

Because owning a dog is not sunshine and rainbows all the time. You are responsible for the dog’s actions, thus you pay for it. When the dog misbehaves you are the one to correct the behavior. You are the one that will feed it, get it toys, play with the dog, take it on walks to relieve itself, provide a comfortable place to sleep, and so much more.

CAN YOU AFFORD A DOG?

This is the one thing most people overlook because they are blinded by the puppy face, smell, licks, etc.

Let me put down some numbers for you:

Description Average Cost
Initial Buy Cost from Breeder 500 – 2500
Initial Buy Cost from Shelter 50 – 200
First Year Vet Expenses 400 – 1500
Spaying or Neutering 300 – 1000
Yearly Vet Costs (no emergencies included; considering a healthy dog) 500 – 1000
Yearly Food (calculated for a medium-size dog, high-quality food price) 700 – 1000
Yearly Supplies and Toys 200 – 500
Yearly Dog Training Classes (assuming a total of 35 weeks per year) 1000 – 1200
Yearly City or Breed Tax (if applies) 100 – 1000
Yearly Petsitter (depends on how often you need one) 150 – 300

The cost of a dog per year is somewhere around $3200 including professional training. Without it, it sums up to about $2200.

My experience with a medium-sized working dog is around $2000 per year without the monthly health and damage insurances.

Bottom line is, a dog can be expensive. So think carefully before you get one if you can afford it.

WHAT IS YOU LIVING SITUATION?

You might want to think twice if a Great Dane is suitable for your little studio apartment, as well as if you want to put a Belgian Malinois into a studio-sized apartment.

If you already have pets or even children, then you need to take into consideration that all pets might not get along with each other and some breeds are not suitable for kids.

Can you isolate sensitive parts of your home? Maybe you don’t want your puppy to be in the kitchen or bathroom.

Also take into consideration, if you are renting your home, that you need consent from your landlord before you get a dog home.

Are you willing to walk up and down the stairs five times a day to walk your dog early in the morning until late at night?

WHAT TYPE OF LIFESTYLE DO YOU HAVE?

Do you like to travel?

Do you work really long hours every day?

You are more on business trips than home? All these can be limiting factors in getting yourself a 4-legged companion.

Consider whether or not you are willing and ready to make changes to your lifestyle to welcome a dog in your life. If you are not ready, now is probably not the right time to get a dog.

If you are willing to make changes, consider the time it will take to provide basic needs such as training, exercise, veterinary and daily care to your dog. Write it down, put it to the side, come back and make a wise decision about it.

DO YOU HAVE ANY DISADVANTAGES?

The first thing that comes into my mind is: are you allergic? If yes then you might want to reconsider taking a furry friend into your home. But if you still want to take a look at hypoallergenic dog breeds.

If you have a sensitive health condition or injury, this can make it difficult to care for a dog, especially if you choose a larger breed. Be mindful of your limitations and choose wisely.

If you are disabled in any way, consider getting a specially trained assistance dog so you can have a companion and built-in helper. Two in one!

A DOG’S SIZE

Don’t let the size fool you, because, most of the time, it doesn’t equal the amount of exercise the dog needs. Small dogs tend to be more hyper and need to be worn out.

Big dogs also require exercise but tend to be a little lazier.

Consider the size of the apartment and common sense will tell you what size of dog you can accommodate.

If you have small kids, keep in mind the breed type you select. Usually, the big dog is a gentle dog, but they also sometimes do not realize the utter enormity of their size and can easily knock down kids.

Dogs are categorized into 5 different size groups, extra small, small, medium, large, extra-large.

A DOG’S ACTIVITY LEVEL

You probably already figured out the fact that some dogs have more energy than others and that a big part of the dog’s activity level is often determined by breed, but it does not mean you can rely on breed alone.

Every dog needs a certain amount of exercise, regardless of breed or size, so make sure you can provide this.

This is something your dog will show you while the two of you get to know each other better.

Be willing to adjust the amount of exercise and attention you give your dog if necessary. Unfortunately, many dogs are given up or even euthanized because of a behavior problem that could have easily been avoided with the proper amount of exercise, training, and attention. Thrive to be a responsible dog owner.

If you know you can not commit to more than one or two casual walks per day, then you will probably be better off with a lower energy dog.

Examples:

  • Newfoundland
  • Basset Hound
  • Greyhound
  • Great Dane
  • Maltese
  • French Bulldog

If you are looking for a dog that can be a jogging partner, agility competitor, Frisbee player, IGP competitions, tracking, man trailing, etc. then consider a Working Dog Breed.

Examples:

  • Alaskan Malamute
  • Siberian Husky
  • Boxer
  • Dobermann Pinscher
  • Rottweiler
  • German Shepherd

If you set your beautiful heart on a specific breed of dog and nothing can sway you in another direction, and you can not provide the huge amount of exercise a young dog might need, consider adopting a mature or senior dog of the desired breed.

A DOG’S TRAINABILITY & INTELLIGENCE

Here are the top 10 smartest dog breeds:

  1. Border Collie
  2. Poodle
  3. German Shepherd
  4. Golden Retriever
  5. Doberman Pinscher
  6. Shetland Sheepdog
  7. Labrador Retriever
  8. Papillon
  9. Rottweiler
  10. Australian Cattle Dog

The smarter the dog, the easier to train in my opinion.

They will learn commands and action sequences much faster and with fewer repetitions. Once you have a good connection with your dog, you will form a team and you will notice somethings your dog will catch even faster than you expect.

I proudly own a number 3 from the list and he amazes me each time with how fast he understands me. By the way, he learned to count! AMAZING!

Training your dog will only bring you benefits. You invest time in the first 2 years of the dog’s life in order to have a relaxed and fun time afterward.

And depending on the breed, your dog is willing to learn, please you and have fun each time you go out with him/her.

Training your dog will create a bond with your dog. It will create a bond you feel deep inside your soul and heart. It will literally be YOUR dog.

You have fun together, you build trust and respect for each other. Treats that will help you out in different situations: new places, meeting new dogs, meeting new people, taking the dog to the vet, etc.

A DOG’S MAINTENANCE

As with all living creatures, dogs can get hurt, they have needs like pee, poop, food, grooming, nail trimming, bathing, cleaning, playing, cuddling, love, boundary setting, so on and so on. Either vet, park or pet store, dogs have needs.

And let’s be very open here: YOU are the one that will provide all that. Make sure you can afford a dog: financially, time-wise and emotionally.

Be ready to connect to your calm, assertive and patient part and be the best dog owner you can be. There is this saying from where I live, that a friend told me:

“You get the dog you deserve!”

WHAT IF … YOU DON’T BUY A PUPPY?

What if instead of adopting a puppy, you go and get an adult dog or even a senior dog? Maybe that is more suitable for you and your present situation.

Keep in mind that the first year in a puppy’s life is more demanding. Yes, they are cute, sure I love them too. I personally enjoy my dog now much more than when he was a puppy.

Maybe a non-suitable, but already adult and trained, police or military dog is an idea for you.

Maybe a shelter adult dog with catches your eye and heart while visiting the local shelter.

Getting an adult dog doesn’t mean that you get it and you have nothing to do. You still have to find that common path for the two of you, but it will have different dynamics as with a puppy.

Maybe you would find it soothing taking in an older soul to keep you company and you will be doing the most selfless action ever by granting a senior dog a good life for the little time he/she has left.

BREED GROUPS & THEIR TEMPERAMENTS

Here is an overview of various types of dog breeds and their main characteristics. Please don’t think that every dog of a specific breed is the same. Like humans, a dog brings and develops its own personality, thus making him or her as unique as you and me.

HERDING GROUP

Herding dogs are very popular as family pets. Especially the collies are excellent family dogs. Their high level of activity and intelligence demand daily high levels of exercise – making them awesome at sports.

They are happier if intellectual stimulation is provided as well.

Herding dogs are very loyal and very willing to work and please their owners. These dogs have been developed for centuries to make independent decisions while working, so don’t be surprised or annoyed if they disobey a command if they think it is in the best interest of the situation at hand.

HOUND GROUP

Hounds are dogs with different talents. Some have extraordinary scenting powers to follow trails while others have an incredible sight view.

Sighthounds are modest and fast dogs, while scent hounds are stronger and harsher.

In size, they range from the tall and slender Irish Wolfhound to the short-legged Dachshund. Being very vigilant, scent hounds nowadays are used by the law enforcement authorities for finding missing persons. Sighthounds serve as the best racing dogs.

NON-SPORTING GROUP

Non-Sporting dogs are a mix of dogs that don’t fit into any category. Some make excellent guard dogs, while others are the perfect house dog.

Their characteristics, size, coat, and personalities differ greatly.

SPORTING GROUP

Sporting dogs are mostly a very active and alert dog breed. They perform best when they have tasks to do or can participate in any kind of dog sport.

These are not dogs to be kept outdoors because they love to be with there human that they adore.

Sporting dogs are intelligent, loyal, and devoted to their families. Many love to swim and quite a few of them are skilled swimmers.

TERRIER GROUP

Terrier dogs are courageous and energetic dogs. Originally bred to hunt and kill vermin, they now are a popular house dog, even as family dogs.

In this breed group, there are many different sizes. They are intelligent, impulsive and very clever.

They solve problems that might not need solving or take an approach their human might not like. Terriers are also independent and stubborn as well as dominant and demanding.

Terriers can be challenging to own because they combine high energy, independence, courage, persistence, and curiosity all in one soul.

TOY GROUP

Toy Group – dog breeds are a descendant of the ancient lapdog or mini versions of hunting/guard dogs.

These dogs were bred down in size to do all kinds of work other dogs couldn’t because of their size. Today they are beloved family pets because they are affectionate, sociable and adaptable to most lifestyles.

Toy Dogs can be loving, cuddly, playful. Much of their exercise needs can be met by running around the home or outside garden or just a short walk.

As a whole, toy breeds are harder to housebreak and will have more accidents in the house than their larger counterparts.

WORKING GROUP

The Working Group – Dog Breeds were bred to assist men in any kind of activities like guarding, pulling, search and rescue, sniffing, assistance and even military.

Their natural need to protect makes these working dogs mostly perfect pets, but they need the proper training.

These dogs are intelligent, robust, powerful, and independent.

They need extensive training to be able to cope with their intelligent being as well as lots of exercises.

Their owner needs to provide a structured environment as well as be a strong and assertive person that will attend their exercise needs and invest the time in the training.

HYBRID GROUP

A mutt can be the right combination of personality and physique as a result of controlled cross-breeding between two dogs that are purebred.

Each variety of hybrid dog is typically called after a combination of parts of their original dog breeds.

For example, Labrador mixed with Poodle resulted in the Labradoodle. Or the Goldendoodle is a mix between Golden Retriever and a Poodle.

There are many new breeds like this and maybe this can also be a good choice for you if you can’t decide between two breeds.

CONCLUSION

Getting the right dog is just the start of what can be a wonderful journey.

“With great power, comes great responsibility.” Marvel’s Spiderman

Honestly, I think getting a dog is a great responsibility but at the same time, it will give you a great power: the power to encounter selfless love. Try it. It is heart soothing and breathtaking

node.postTitle: The 7 Types of Dog Breeds Explained

postDescription.postDescription: Dog breeds are split up in 7 types and categorized as follow: Sporting Group, Working Group, Toy Group, Herding Group, Hound Group, Terrier Group, Non-Sporting Group.

categoryDescription.categoryDescription: All you need to know about dog breeds from their personality and temperament to a little bit of history, health, and care.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Sporting Group

Naturally active and alert, Sporting Dogs make likable and well-rounded companions.

Typically pointers and setters would identify and mark game by pointing, spaniels would flush the game out, and retrievers would be in charge of recovering dead and wounded game.

Known for their superior instincts in water and woods, many of these breeds enjoy hunting and other field activities.

Many of them, especially the water-retrieving breeds, have well insulated and water repellant coats, which makes these breads quite resilient to the elements.

There are four basic types of Sporting Dogs:

  • Spaniels
  • Pointers
  • Retrievers
  • Setters

Spaniels

In assisting hunters, Spaniels work within gun range, are steady to shots, able to mark the fall and retrieve shot game with a soft mouth.

A good nose is highly valued, as it is in most gun dog breeds.

They are versatile hunters and whether hunting in open fields, woodlands, farmlands, in briars, along fencerows or marshlands, a spaniel can get the job done.

Spaniel Breeds

  • American Cocker Spaniel
  • American Water Spaniel
  • Blue Picardy Spaniel
  • Boykin Spaniel
  • Cavalier King Charles Spaniel
  • Clumber Spaniel
  • Drentse Patrijshond
  • English Cocker Spaniel
  • English Springer Spaniel
  • Field Spaniel
  • German Spaniel
  • Irish Water Spaniel
  • King Charles Spaniel
  • Kooikerhondje
  • Markiesje
  • Papillon
  • Phalene
  • Picardy Spaniel
  • Pont-Audemer Spaniel
  • Russian Spaniel
  • Stabyhoun
  • Sussex Spaniel
  • Welsh Springer Spaniel

Pointers

These dogs are trained for field reconnaissance.

The moment they sense the prey they freeze in the position they caught the prey’s smell and remain like a statue with a lifted paw and the snout pointing in the direction of the prey.

They freeze in this position until released by the hunter.

They are big sized dogs, with expressive eyes, big and floppy ears, a very good sense of smell and with a special passion for searching the prey.

The Pointers are active through their character, submissive, loyal, and gentle.

Having a pretty powerful hunter instinct, they are not trustful around small animals, including cats.

Many from these dogs were raised to work far away from the hunter and could have independent thinking, and have the tendency to roam.

Pointer Breeds

  • Brittany
  • French Brittany
  • English Pointer
  • German Shorthaired Pointer
  • German Wirehaired Pointer
  • German Longhaired Pointer
  • German Roughhaired Pointer
  • Italian Spinone
  • Pudelpointer
  • Small Munsterlander
  • Large Munsterlander
  • Old Danish Pointer
  • Vizsla
  • Wirehaired Viszla
  • Weimaraner
  • Wirehaired Pointing Griffon
  • Burgos Pointer
  • Portuguese Pointer
  • Slovakian Wirehaired Pointer
  • Cesky Fousek
  • Arrange Pointer

Retrievers

Retrievers are originally hunting dogs whose job was to collect the kill.

That is, the different breeds of this type of dog were bred and trained to collect the game and bring it back to the hunter.

The retriever’s willingness to please, patient nature and trainability have made breeds such as the Labrador Retriever and Golden Retriever popular as a disability assistance dog.

Retriever Breeds

  • Chesapeake Bay Retriever
  • Curly Coated Retriever
  • Flat-Coated Retriever
  • Golden Retriever
  • Labrador Retriever
  • Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever

Setters

A Setter silently searches for game by scent. When prey is encountered the Setter freezes rather than chasing after the game.

Setters get their name from their distinctive stance: a sort of crouch or “set” upon finding their quarry.

Setter tend to be happy, playful dogs and are usually very friendly both to people and other dogs.

They have a great deal of energy and require daily exercise.

Setter Breeds

  • English Setter
  • Gordon Setter
  • Irish Red Setter
  • Irish Red and White Setter
  • Llewellin Setter

Working Group

Dogs that are categorized into the Working Group have historically been responsible for tasks ranging from pulling sleds and carts to guarding flocks and homes.

These dogs include farm and draft animals, security, police, and military dogs, as well as guide and service dogs.

As such, they make dependable, loyal pets with incredible intelligence and energy.

Without the right training, some working dogs can be difficult to handle, even dangerous, some working dog breeds may not be for the first-time dog owner.

There are over 50 dogs in this group, so I mention here the most popular ones.

Working Dog Breeds

  • Rottweiler
  • Boxer
  • Siberian Husky
  • Great Dane
  • Doberman Pinscher
  • Mastiff
  • Bernese Mountain Dog
  • Cane Corso
  • Newfoundland
  • Akita
  • St.Bernard
  • Portuguese Water Dog
  • Bullmastiff
  • Alaskan Malamute

Toy Group

The toy breed was bred for the purpose of serving as companions for their humans.

These small, easily portable dogs can be most often found sitting in the lap of their humans or being carried around, have been bred down from their larger cousins.

Ideal for anyone with limited space, these little fellas are intelligent, sociable, and full of energy, and despite their small stature, many do have strong protective instincts and big personalities.

There are over 20 dogs in this group, so I mention here the most popular ones.

Toy Group Breeds

  • Silky Terrier
  • English Toy Spaniel
  • Yorkshire Terrier
  • Affenpinscher
  • Toy Poodle
  • Beaglier
  • Bolognese Dog
  • Biewer Terrier
  • Russian Tsvetnaya Bolonka
  • Toy Manchester Terrier

Herding Group

This group includes 30 breeds in a wide variety of sizes, from the Corgi to the German Shepherd with the most straightforward task. Herding dogs have historically been bred to gather, herd, and protect livestock, and work closely with human shepherds. Today, some like the Belgian Malinois and the German Shepherd Dog are commonly used for police, military and protection work. Herding Dogs are highly intelligent and trainable, with a huge desire to please their loved ones.

Herding Group Breeds

  • Collie
  • Briard
  • Pumi
  • Icelandic Sheepdog
  • Entlebucher Mountain Dog
  • Puli
  • Finnish Lapphund
  • Norwegian Buhund

Hound Group

The Hound Dogs are dogs that have specifically been bred to pursue a warm-blooded game.

This group encompasses a diverse array of breeds.

Generally, the charming, affectionate dogs in this group will make loyal companions and family pets.

Some will require more vigorous exercise than others and more intense training than some.

There are three types of hound, with several breeds within each type:

  • Sight Hounds
  • Scent Hounds
  • Miscellaneous Hounds

Sight Hounds

Sight Hounds Sleek, long-legged sighthounds rely on their explosive speed, incredible stamina, and sharp, wide vision to chase fast animals like jackrabbits and antelope and either bring them down or hold them at bay until the hunter arrives.

Sight Hound Breeds

  • Afghan Hound
  • Azawakh
  • Borzoi
  • Galgo Barbucho Patagonica
  • Galgo Espanol
  • Greyhound
  • Hortaya Borzaya
  • Irish Wolfhound
  • Italian Greyhound
  • Magyar Agar
  • Polish Greyhound
  • Saluki
  • Schottish Deerhound
  • Silken Windhound
  • Whippet

Scent Hounds

Scent hounds are responsible for using their acute sense of smell to track game and are known for being more rugged and durable and having the ability to trail just about anything—whether it’s a squirrel or a missing person.

Scent Hound Breeds

  • American Black and Tan Coonhound
  • Bluetick Coonhound
  • American English Coonhound

  • Alpine Dachsbracke

Miscellaneous Hounds

A number of breeds do not hunt solely by speed, sight, and scent, pursuing their prey using both sight and scent.

These breeds are difficult to classify, as they are neither sighthounds nor scenthounds.

Miscellaneous Hound Breeds

  • Podenco Canario
  • Cirneco dell’ Etna
  • Podenco Ibicenco
  • Pharaoh Hound
  • Portuguese Podengo
  • Rhodesian Ridgeback
  • Peruvian Inca Orchid
  • Thai Ridgeback

Terrier Group

Terrier is a type of dog originally created to hunt earthy animals: rats, moles, badgers.

Terrier breeds vary greatly in size and form, but there’s one thing which is common to all is their feisty, mischievous personality and energetic nature.

Even small terriers take the “I’m in charge” attitude which can be a problem if they’re not socialized and trained.

They will challenge much bigger dogs, so you must be on your toes when around other dogs.

Bull Terrier breeds were once created for bull baiting and dogfights, but, happily, they are now some of today’s companion dogs.

Non-Sporting Group

The only thing the dogs in the non-sporting group have in common is that they don’t have enough in common with the breeds of any other group.

The Non-Sporting Dogs are all the dogs that remain. They vary greatly in size, function, and history.

Most of these dogs make generally good house dogs and watchdogs, but with breeds ranging from the French Bulldog to the Poodle, their differences are so vast that it makes it difficult to generalize their individual traits.

Non-Sporting Dog Breeds
